Not to be outdone in this season
of: banquets and general reunions,
the Johns Hopkins Musical _Club
held its annual dinner .and election
Of officers Monday night at the Hotel Emerson. About fifty members
were present.
When the last course of the banquet proper was cleared away and
the smokes passed around, "Mike"
Tilghman, president, presented Mr.
Hobart Smock, the popular director of this year's glee club. There
followed a- rising; - roaring vote of
thanks for the popular leader's services during the year. Mr. Smock
retaliated with a long string of his
favorite jokes. They were all good
jokes, very • good—the kind that
never grow old. And Mr. Smock
sat down with applause and laughter ringing in his ears.

publication, and Keller is football manager. All hold numerous other positions in other

if the following nameless and anonymous contribution—which

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 8, 1925
THE LITERARY SUPPLEMENT
About three years ago there appeared under the aegis of
the university a surprising and interesting publication, which
bore on its cover, in great red letters, the title HORIZONS.
The editors announced on the last page that "until we have
swept the horizons free of smoke and haze we shall not cease.
In the fall we shall sweep again.—Look for us." We have
looked. But apparently other brooms were busy as well, and
the publishers of HORIZONS, or at any rate the more enterprising of them, were swept from the groves of Homewood—
through no inhospitality on the part of Homewood, we hasten
to add.
Whether they felt that their mission, which they
seemed to take very seriously, was accomplished, or whether
their energy was exhausted by the really rather good things
they did accomplish, we do not know. At all events, HORIZONS lapsed. Three years have passed, and during that time
steam has gradually accumulated again. Though the kettle may
not be boiling furiously, nevertheless it threatens to lift the lid
which has settled so peacefully and unprotestingly. How high
it will jump, or how often, no one knows.
That depends on the undergraduates, who are a very uncertain lot. Some few have responded nobly. But they have
been chiefly those who were already counted on. And one important reason for such a venture as a literary supplement is,
that it may uncover some one whom it had not expected at all.
It may even be hoped that it will encourage or stimulate such a
person. And there is one particular direction in which it would
like to do a little stimulating. That is toward serious prose,
narrative or descriptive. Poets may be trusted generally to
take care of themselves.
Young writers seem to feel too
often that if they are not writing verse they are not writing
at all. As a matter of fact good narrative prose is quite as rare
as good verse. And on that particular subject which the undergraduate is particularly qualified to treat, it is so rare as to
be almost non-existent. We mean intelligent artistic treatment of undergraduate life. Young writers have a bias toward the romantic, and a too modest opinion of the importance
and interest of their own activities. This is unfortunate, because few things would be more interesting than a serious study
of that large part of America which is in attendance at her huge
universities. Why not begin it at Hopkins? A sort of swansong, in this case; let the "despised undergraduate", as he has
been wont to call himself lately, prove, if not his right to exist,
at any rate his actual existence, which some have even dared to
doubt.
One principle we adhere to now, and will adhere to firmly
in the future, we hope. It has been said often since the days of
HORIZONS that what Hopkins really needs, is a literary magazine. This we venture to doubt. If Hopkins had needed a lit- •
erary magazine it would have had it long ago. Such things are
not to be forced. If they do not make themselves it is futile ai4
foolish to try to make them. We shall not try. We are not
so ambitious as HORIZONS. We have serious doubts about
our continued existence. We hope we shall be able to retire as
gracefully as our predecessors, if we find we are not wanted.
Not that we do not want to stay. We are ambitious; we
hope we shall be energetic; still more that we shall deserve the
interest which we have already aroused. But we cannot, or will
not, do it by ourselves.
T. T.

But to return to our sympathizings with the distressing
conditions of local co-ed-dom, we recall a student vote (of
which interesting events, by the way, there are far too few) on
this question, conducted by the NEWS-LETTER about two
years ago. The result was an overwhelming condemnation of
the co-educational system, at least as applied to Hopkins. We
have since wondered at this, and, of late, our speculations have
taken a cynical tone.
As we see it, there were at least five factors, of varying
importance, behind this vote:
Men, in general, are secretly suspicious, highly skeptical
and even a little resentful of higher education for women. This
attitude probably has much to do with the preservation of superiority complexes, doubtless soundly based on social history.
As a result, men are equally suspicious of the type of women likely to be found in co-educational institutions, i. e., where
men are also taught, i. e., where higher education is ordinarily
highest.
Men want to air their knowledge in mixed company as if
it were innate. Thus, the men are not anxious to have feminine eyes witness so vulgar a process as the acquiring of learning, especially when the girls are in a position to pass judgments on masculine receptivity.
In the daily class-to-class races, .there would be little opportunity for the boys to enjoy, leisurely, the feminine society
so near and yet so far away. The girls would be a distraction,
an intriguing and insufficient glimpse.
The day to day activity of boys is not the constantly topnotch existence that the average girl's can be, when she so
desires.

1925 Book Will Appear May 20; Staff
to Hold Banquet; Three
Men Make Staff

The 1926 Hullabaloo has signed
a contract with the White Studio
of New York to make all the necessary photographs for the Annual, it was announced yesterday
by Henry R. Turnbull, Editor-inChief of the book.
"The quality of work, the cooperation offered, and the excellent contract of the White Studios
were the determining factors in
making the choice," Turnbull said.
"Anyone who has seen the proofs
of the pictures for this year's
book will testify that the photography was satisfactory in every
particular."
Underclassmen Appointed

Three appointments to the Business Staff of the 1925 Hullabaloo
were announced yesterday by
George Hess, Business Manager.
For meritorious work in securing advertisements, Leonard Dalsemer '28, Charles F. Reese '27,
and Milton Myerberg '28 were
given positions. The advertising
contracts have now passed the $1,000.00 mark, which is sufficient to
make the book a financial success.
The Hullabaloo will appear
May 20, according to James R.
Young, Editor of this year's book.
Young is working day and night,
giving his personal supervision to
making up the Annual. There
will be a large number of special
features.
Young will give a banquet for
both staffs on May 28 at the
Southern Hotel. This is the first
time for a number of years that
the Hullabaloo has given such a
banquet. At that time each man
on the Editorial and Business
Staffs will receive a personal copy
of the Hullabaloo with his name
stamped on the cover in gold.

DEBATERS WIN
Winslow Davies and John
Webster carried Hopkins colors to victory in the Southern
section of the annual Triangular Debate last Thursday,
winning from Washington
and Lee. The Hopkins men
upheld the negative side of
the question, "Resolved: That
the States should pass the
Proposed Child Labor Amendment to the Constitution."

Attended Registrar's Convention
in Colorado

R. N. Dempster, Registrar, represented Johns Hopkins University at a recent annual meeting
of the American Association of
Collegiate Registrars, at Boulder
City, Colorado. In the course of
his trip, Mr. Dempster stopped at
Iowa City, Cedar Rapids, Des
Moines, and Omaha, for the purpose of organizing local alumni
groups in those places.
Problems Discussed

At the convention of the Registrars the problems of the registrar's office at various universities
were discussed. The universities
in the association number 150 and
include the largest institutions in
the United States. Such problems
were discussed by these representatives as "A Uniform Method of
Reporting Grades of Student Organizations," an attempt to facilitate the gathering of statistics;
and "The Honor System, Its Extent and Application."
The membership to the organization is classified Institutional
rather than individual. That is
John Hopkins University is enrolled as a member and Mr.
Dempster is the University's representative. In the recent convention Mr. Dempster submitted the
report of one of the major committees.

FIELD CLUB VISITS ANT ENGLISHMAN TO SPEAK AT FINAL R. 0. T. C. REVIEW
TO BE ON MAY 18
NEXT ASSEMBLY
HILLS AT TIMONIUM
OF STUDENTS
"C" Company Leading in IntercomDr. Andrews Leads Scientific Expedition
to Study Insects
Richards, Well Known
Rev. Leyton Richards
Pacifist, to
Ant hills in the neighborhood

of Timonium were sought and examined in the excursion of the
Field Club a week ago last 'Wednesday.
Nine persons, including Dr. E.
A. Andrews, left the University
in automobiles at one o'clock to
seek the haunts of the big red
ants. The hills were discovered
withput difficulty, but the ants
themselves were hiding deep
down in the mounds, out of reach
of the cold, raw atmosphere.
Dr. Andrews has been experimenting with the little insects for
several years. Only last winter he
removed some of the upper layers
of frozen mounds to examine their
texture and construction. These
gaps in the hills were found to
have been entirely repaired by the
ants in the few warm days this
spring. As Dr. Andrews expressed it, "Like Baltimore after the
great fire, a general destruction of
homes quickly produced a growth
of a new and better type."

Reverend Leyton Richards of
Carr's Lane Church, Birmingham, England, will be the speaker
at the next assembly, May 14.
Mr. Richards came to the United
States in March for a threemonths' tour of the leading
churches, clubs, universities. He
is spreading the doctrine of world
friendship.
Reverend Richards was born in
England, but spent a part of his
boyhood in Grand Rapids, Michigan. During his student days at
Oxford, he spent three summers
as pastor of a church in Richmond, Me. He has filled pastorates successively at Peterhead,
Scotland; Melbourne, Australia,
and the Bowdon Church near
Manchester, England. A few
years ago he came to this country
to preach for six months in alternation with Rev. Richard Roberts
in Brooklyn. For a year after the
war Rev. Richards occupied a
pulpit in Liverpool; he was then
called back to the Bowdon
Church, from which he went to
Birmingham.
Reverend Richards is a strong
pacifist and was greatly opposed
to the world war.

Competition; "B" Second

The final drill of the R. 0. T. C.
which will be held on May 18 is
now attracting the attention of the
cadets. On that date, the Unit
will be reviewed by Major General
S. E. Sturgis, Dr. Ames, a Military Committee, and other notables. In the absence of Dr. Goodnow, who is in Europe, Dr. Ames
will represent the University.
The best drilled man and company will be selected. The former
will receive a medal and the latter
a cup. G. E. Marley won the
medal last year. The cup was won
by Company "C." The cup is not
permanent, the winning company
holding it for only one year.

Report Shows Successful
Season in All Respects

Not to be outdone in this season
of: banquets and general reunions,
the Johns Hopkins Musical _Club
held its annual dinner .and election
Of officers Monday night at the Hotel Emerson. About fifty members
were present.
When the last course of the banquet proper was cleared away and
the smokes passed around, "Mike"
Tilghman, president, presented Mr.
Hobart Smock, the popular director of this year's glee club. There
followed a- rising; - roaring vote of
thanks for the popular leader's services during the year. Mr. Smock
retaliated with a long string of his
favorite jokes. They were all good
jokes, very • good—the kind that
never grow old. And Mr. Smock
sat down with applause and laughter ringing in his ears.

THREE MEN ADMITTED
TO ODK MEMBERSHIP
Gordon M. Stick,'26, Ludlow H. Baldwin '26, and Otho
J. Keller III '26, were publicly initiated into Omicron
Delta Kappa at the Assembly
of the Student Body yesterday. The private ceremony
was held at the Dormitories
Commons Room last night.
All three of the initiates are
Juniors and hold prominent
positions in various campus
activities. Stick is Editor of
the Blue Jay, Baldwin is Business Manager of the same
publication, and Keller is football manager. All hold numerous other positions in other
activities.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 8, 1925
THE LITERARY SUPPLEMENT
About three years ago there appeared under the aegis of
the university a surprising and interesting publication, which
bore on its cover, in great red letters, the title HORIZONS.
The editors announced on the last page that "until we have
swept the horizons free of smoke and haze we shall not cease.
In the fall we shall sweep again.—Look for us." We have
looked. But apparently other brooms were busy as well, and
the publishers of HORIZONS, or at any rate the more enterprising of them, were swept from the groves of Homewood—
through no inhospitality on the part of Homewood, we hasten
to add.
Whether they felt that their mission, which they
seemed to take very seriously, was accomplished, or whether
their energy was exhausted by the really rather good things
they did accomplish, we do not know. At all events, HORIZONS lapsed. Three years have passed, and during that time
steam has gradually accumulated again. Though the kettle may
not be boiling furiously, nevertheless it threatens to lift the lid
which has settled so peacefully and unprotestingly. How high
it will jump, or how often, no one knows.
That depends on the undergraduates, who are a very uncertain lot. Some few have responded nobly. But they have
been chiefly those who were already counted on. And one important reason for such a venture as a literary supplement is,
that it may uncover some one whom it had not expected at all.
It may even be hoped that it will encourage or stimulate such a
person. And there is one particular direction in which it would
like to do a little stimulating. That is toward serious prose,
narrative or descriptive. Poets may be trusted generally to
take care of themselves.
Young writers seem to feel too
often that if they are not writing verse they are not writing
at all. As a matter of fact good narrative prose is quite as rare
as good verse. And on that particular subject which the undergraduate is particularly qualified to treat, it is so rare as to
be almost non-existent. We mean intelligent artistic treatment of undergraduate life. Young writers have a bias toward the romantic, and a too modest opinion of the importance
and interest of their own activities. This is unfortunate, because few things would be more interesting than a serious study
of that large part of America which is in attendance at her huge
universities. Why not begin it at Hopkins? A sort of swansong, in this case; let the "despised undergraduate", as he has
been wont to call himself lately, prove, if not his right to exist,
at any rate his actual existence, which some have even dared to
doubt.
One principle we adhere to now, and will adhere to firmly
in the future, we hope. It has been said often since the days of
HORIZONS that what Hopkins really needs, is a literary magazine. This we venture to doubt. If Hopkins had needed a lit- •
erary magazine it would have had it long ago. Such things are
not to be forced. If they do not make themselves it is futile ai4
foolish to try to make them. We shall not try. We are not
so ambitious as HORIZONS. We have serious doubts about
our continued existence. We hope we shall be able to retire as
gracefully as our predecessors, if we find we are not wanted.
Not that we do not want to stay. We are ambitious; we
hope we shall be energetic; still more that we shall deserve the
interest which we have already aroused. But we cannot, or will
not, do it by ourselves.
T. T.

But to return to our sympathizings with the distressing
conditions of local co-ed-dom, we recall a student vote (of
which interesting events, by the way, there are far too few) on
this question, conducted by the NEWS-LETTER about two
years ago. The result was an overwhelming condemnation of
the co-educational system, at least as applied to Hopkins. We
have since wondered at this, and, of late, our speculations have
taken a cynical tone.
As we see it, there were at least five factors, of varying
importance, behind this vote:
Men, in general, are secretly suspicious, highly skeptical
and even a little resentful of higher education for women. This
attitude probably has much to do with the preservation of superiority complexes, doubtless soundly based on social history.
As a result, men are equally suspicious of the type of women likely to be found in co-educational institutions, i. e., where
men are also taught, i. e., where higher education is ordinarily
highest.
Men want to air their knowledge in mixed company as if
it were innate. Thus, the men are not anxious to have feminine eyes witness so vulgar a process as the acquiring of learning, especially when the girls are in a position to pass judgments on masculine receptivity.
In the daily class-to-class races, .there would be little opportunity for the boys to enjoy, leisurely, the feminine society
so near and yet so far away. The girls would be a distraction,
an intriguing and insufficient glimpse.
The day to day activity of boys is not the constantly topnotch existence that the average girl's can be, when she so
desires.

The 1926 Hullabaloo has signed
a contract with the White Studio
of New York to make all the necessary photographs for the Annual, it was announced yesterday
by Henry R. Turnbull, Editor-inChief of the book.
"The quality of work, the cooperation offered, and the excellent contract of the White Studios

"Anyone who has seen the proofs
of the pictures for this year's
book will testify that the photography was satisfactory in every
particular."
Underclassmen Appointed

Three appointments to the Business Staff of the 1925 Hullabaloo
were announced yesterday by
George Hess, Business Manager.
For meritorious work in securing advertisements, Leonard Dalsemer '28, Charles F. Reese '27,
and Milton Myerberg '28 were
given positions. The advertising
contracts have now passed the $1,000.00 mark, which is sufficient to
make the book a financial success.
The Hullabaloo will appear
May 20, according to James R.
Young, Editor of this year's book.
Young is working day and night,
giving his personal supervision to
making up the Annual. There
will be a large number of special
features.
Young will give a banquet for
both staffs on May 28 at the
Southern Hotel. This is the first
time for a number of years that
the Hullabaloo has given such a
banquet. At that time each man
on the Editorial and Business
Staffs will receive a personal copy
of the Hullabaloo with his name
stamped on the cover in gold.

DEBATERS WIN
Winslow Davies and John
Webster carried Hopkins colors to victory in the Southern
section of the annual Triangular Debate last Thursday,
winning from Washington
and Lee. The Hopkins men
upheld the negative side of
the question, "Resolved: That
the States should pass the
Proposed Child Labor Amendment to the Constitution."

Attended Registrar's Convention
in Colorado

R. N. Dempster, Registrar, represented Johns Hopkins University at a recent annual meeting
of the American Association of
Collegiate Registrars, at Boulder
City, Colorado. In the course of
his trip, Mr. Dempster stopped at
Iowa City, Cedar Rapids, Des
Moines, and Omaha, for the purpose of organizing local alumni
groups in those places.
Problems Discussed

At the convention of the Registrars the problems of the registrar's office at various universities
were discussed. The universities
in the association number 150 and
include the largest institutions in
the United States. Such problems
were discussed by these representatives as "A Uniform Method of
Reporting Grades of Student Organizations," an attempt to facilitate the gathering of statistics;
and "The Honor System, Its Extent and Application."
The membership to the organization is classified Institutional
rather than individual. That is
John Hopkins University is enrolled as a member and Mr.
Dempster is the University's representative. In the recent convention Mr. Dempster submitted the
report of one of the major committees.

OF STUDENTS
"C" Company Leading in IntercomDr. Andrews Leads Scientific Expedition
to Study Insects
Richards, Well Known
Rev. Leyton Richards
Pacifist, to
Ant hills in the neighborhood

of Timonium were sought and examined in the excursion of the
Field Club a week ago last 'Wednesday.
Nine persons, including Dr. E.
A. Andrews, left the University
in automobiles at one o'clock to
seek the haunts of the big red
ants. The hills were discovered
withput difficulty, but the ants
themselves were hiding deep
down in the mounds, out of reach
of the cold, raw atmosphere.
Dr. Andrews has been experimenting with the little insects for
several years. Only last winter he
removed some of the upper layers
of frozen mounds to examine their
texture and construction. These
gaps in the hills were found to
have been entirely repaired by the
ants in the few warm days this
spring. As Dr. Andrews expressed it, "Like Baltimore after the
great fire, a general destruction of
homes quickly produced a growth
of a new and better type."

Reverend Leyton Richards of
Carr's Lane Church, Birmingham, England, will be the speaker
at the next assembly, May 14.
Mr. Richards came to the United
States in March for a threemonths' tour of the leading
churches, clubs, universities. He
is spreading the doctrine of world
friendship.
Reverend Richards was born in
England, but spent a part of his
boyhood in Grand Rapids, Michigan. During his student days at
Oxford, he spent three summers
as pastor of a church in Richmond, Me. He has filled pastorates successively at Peterhead,
Scotland; Melbourne, Australia,
and the Bowdon Church near
Manchester, England. A few
years ago he came to this country
to preach for six months in alternation with Rev. Richard Roberts
in Brooklyn. For a year after the
war Rev. Richards occupied a
pulpit in Liverpool; he was then
called back to the Bowdon
Church, from which he went to
Birmingham.
Reverend Richards is a strong
pacifist and was greatly opposed
to the world war.
